prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
The selected galaxies all have dust masses >3x10^5 Msun, as measured using our multi-band Herschel imaging (Fuller et al., 2014). Using a conservative molecular gas-to-dust ratio of 50 (e.g. Smith et al., 2012) we expect each object to have at least 10^7 Msun of molecular gas. A few of the sample galaxies have shallow CO(1-0) single-dish fluxes from the SEST survey of Horellou et al (1995), and indeed their H$_2$ masses are all greater than 5x10^7 Msun.
We propose to map these objects to a 5 sigma surface density limit of ~5 Msun pc^-2 in each 10 km/s channel. This will ensure we create a good map of each resolved source, which is sensitive enough to detect truncations caused by ram-pressure (e.g. Davis et al., 2013), and has sufficient resolution to resolve the gas kinematics. This will also ensure that our survey has consistent data quality. Note that an unresolved gas cloud with 5 Msun/pc^2 would correspond to about 5x10^5 Msun of molecular gas at this distance and resolution. This sensitivity is at least as good as that reached by surveys of Virgo cluster and field objects (e.g. Regan et al., 2001, Alatalo et al., 2013) ensuring we can compare directly.
In order to convert this surface brightness requirement to flux within our ALMA beam we use a `standard' CO-to-H_2 X-factor of 2x10^20. This X-factor is thought to be applicable for these large galaxies in high-metallicity environments like Fornax; Dickman, Snell & Schloerb 1986). We take the most conservative case where our object is observed face on, and a beam size of 3.4". The standard formula for converting between surface density and flux (see e.g. Davis et al., 2013) shows that to fulfil our science goals we need 4.0 mJy/beam, to reach a 5 sigma surface density limit of ~5 Msun pc^-2 in each 10 km/s channel.

We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems, as it is the line that is most closely linked to molecular gas mass. The total CO line widths in these object range from 30-250 km/s, as found by Horellou et al. We thus base our sensitivity estimate on 10 km/s channels, to ensure we have at least 3 channels per line. This resolution will also allow us to conduct accurate kinematic studies of these objects. We thus propose to use a 1875 MHz baseband placed on 12CO, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (~3 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. Face on sources tend to be brighter in each channel than edge on galaxies, and this configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning, or increase it, at will to get higher sensitivity and better kinematics. We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (90 km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

We request the lowest resolution of 3.4" (~280 pc at the distance of Fornax) for this study in order to reasonably match the resolution of available ancillary data (Herschel ~7 arcsec, GALEX 5 arcsec), and ensure our data is comparable to the CO maps available for other clusters (e.g. 4-5 arcsec; Alatalo et al., 2012). This will also allow us to achieve the high surface brightness sensitivity in reasonably short integrations.
This science goal contains 5 sources which our Herschel imaging reveal have sufficiently elongated gas and dust reservoirs to need a small mosaic cover all the gas. All of the sources contained in this science goal are edge on galaxies, and at the angular resolution we request the sources will be unresolved in each channel along the kinematic axis of the system (tracing the `spider diagram'). One of these source is undergoing ram-pressure stripping, and so CO emission may be resolved within each channel, but would be expected to be highly clumpy. Thus in all these case the largest angular scale is always smaller than 20", which means that we do not expect to resolve out flux, and hence we do not request ACA observations. With the 36 antennas available in Cycle-3 (and the advantageous calibrator sharing mode) the UV coverage obtained will be more than sufficient to make good images, even with the short integration times requested here.

The selected galaxies all have dust masses >3x10^5 Msun, as measured using our multi-band Herschel imaging (Fuller et al., 2014). Using a conservative molecular gas-to-dust ratio of 50 (e.g. Smith et al., 2012) we expect each object to have at least 10^7 Msun of molecular gas. A few of the sample galaxies have shallow CO(1-0) single-dish fluxes from the SEST survey of Horellou et al (1995), and indeed their H$_2$ masses are all greater than 5x10^7 Msun.
We propose to map these objects to a 5 sigma surface density limit of ~5 Msun pc^-2 in each 10 km/s channel. This will ensure we create a good map of each resolved source, which is sensitive enough to detect truncations caused by ram-pressure (e.g. Davis et al., 2013), and has sufficient resolution to resolve the gas kinematics. This will also ensure that our survey has consistent data quality. Note that an unresolved gas cloud with 5 Msun/pc^2 would correspond to about 5x10^5 Msun of molecular gas at this distance and resolution. This sensitivity is at least as good as that reached by surveys of Virgo cluster and field objects (e.g. Regan et al., 2001, Alatalo et al., 2013) ensuring we can compare directly.
In order to convert this surface brightness requirement to flux within our ALMA beam we use a `standard' CO-to-H_2 X-factor of 2x10^20. This X-factor is thought to be applicable for these large galaxies in high-metallicity environments like Fornax; Dickman, Snell & Schloerb 1986). We take the most conservative case where our object is observed face on, and a beam size of 3.4". The standard formula for converting between surface density and flux (see e.g. Davis et al., 2013) shows that to fulfil our science goals we need 4.0 mJy/beam, to reach a 5 sigma surface density limit of ~5 Msun pc^-2 in each 10 km/s channel.

We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems, as it is the line that is most closely linked to molecular gas mass. The total CO line widths in these object range from 30-250 km/s, as found by Horellou et al. We thus base our sensitivity estimate on 10 km/s channels, to ensure we have at least 3 channels per line. This resolution will also allow us to conduct accurate kinematic studies of these objects. We thus propose to use a 1875 MHz baseband placed on 12CO, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (~3 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. Face on sources tend to be brighter in each channel than edge on galaxies, and this configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning, or increase it, at will to get higher sensitivity and better kinematics. We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (90 km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

We request the lowest resolution of 3.4" (~280 pc at the distance of Fornax) for this study in order to reasonably match the resolution of available ancillary data (Herschel ~7 arcsec, GALEX 5 arcsec), and ensure our data is comparable to the CO maps available for other clusters (e.g. 4-5 arcsec; Alatalo et al., 2012). This will also allow us to achieve the high surface brightness sensitivity in reasonably short integrations.
This science goal contains 13 sources which our Herschel imaging reveal have sufficiently compact CO reservoirs to allow a single pointing to cover all the gas. Experience shows that at the angular resolution we request the sources will be marginally resolved in each channel along the kinematic axis of the system (tracing the `spider diagram') and thus only the minor axis size where we expect molecular gas is important when considering the largest angular size of the source. At this resolution the maximum angular scale detectable is ~25 arcsec. These objects all have minor axes that are sufficiently small (<20") that we do not expect to resolve out flux here, and hence we do not require ACA observations. With the 36 antennas available in Cycle-3 (and the advantageous calibrator sharing mode) the UV coverage obtained will be more than sufficient to make good images, even with the short integration times requested here.

The selected dwarf galaxies all have dust masses >3x10^5 Msun, and thus using a conservative molecular gas-to-dust ratio of 100 (as found in the SMC e.g. Leroy et al., 2007) we expect each object to have at least ~10^7 Msun of molecular gas. The CO linewidths are expected to be 30-80 km/s. We thus base our sensitivity estimate on 10 km/s channels, to ensure we have at least 3 channels per line. As a guide we use a CO-to-H_2 X-factor of 2x10^21 (appropriate for galaxies of the lowest mass we probe, metallicites of 12+log(O/H)=8.3; Schruba et al., 2012), which is a similar mass to the majority of these objects), and an average line width of 50 km/s, and estimate that we need 2.8 mJy/beam in 10 km/s channels to ensure a 5 sigma detection of 25 Msun pc^2 in these objects. At this surface brightness we would sucessfully map the vast majority of the gas in the LMC, and IC10, local analogues of these objects.

We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems, as it is the line that is most closely linked to molecular gas mass. The total CO line widths in these low mass objects are expected to be 30-80 km/s. We thus base our sensitivity estimate on 10 km/s channels, to ensure we have at least 3 channels per line. This resolution will also allow us to conduct kinematic studies of these objects. We thus propose to use a 1875 MHz baseband placed on 12CO, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz (~3 km/s), which we will bin up to 10 km/s in post processing. Face on sources tend to be brighter in each channel than edge on galaxies, and this configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning, or increase it, at will to get higher sensitivity and better kinematics. We use the other available basebands in continuum mode, with 31MHz (90 km/s) resolution to give us the ability to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

We request the resolution of 4" for this study of dwarfs. This will allow us to achieve the high surface brightness sensitivity required in reasonably short integrations. These dwarf galaxies are compact, allowing a single pointing to cover all the galaxy, and its associated gas. At the angular resolution we request the sources will be marginally resolved, so we do not expect to resolve out flux, and hence we do not require ACA observations. With the 36 antennas available in Cycle-3 (and the advantageous calibrator sharing mode) the UV coverage obtained will be more than sufficient to make good images if the gas is resolved, even with the integration times requested here.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map the molecular reservoirs of a complete sample of dust and atomic gas detected galaxies in the Fornax cluster, the nearest representative of the groups and poor clusters in which most galaxies in the universe reside. Combined with our teams complimentary Herschel/ATCA/MeerKAT data we will construct the first complete census of the cool interstellar medium in this cluster. These ALMA data will allow us to understand the effect environment has on molecular gas, through ram-pressure, strangulation & harassment. We will probe the ISM in cluster dwarf galaxies, shed light on the physical cause of the gas disk truncation and morphological transformation, and provide a local baseline for galaxy scaling relations. This project will also have strong legacy value, as this will be the only cluster with homogenous data across wavebands, mapping its galaxy population (from dwarfs to massive galaxies) in exquisite detail. This will directly lead to a greater understanding of the environmental processes quenching and morphologically transforming galaxies in dense environments.
